physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. The words “Poetry (Monroe)” are written in pencil in the top center of the first page. The words “H.M. – Page 2” are typewritten in the top left corner of the second page. The bottom left corner of the first page is folded inward, and the bottom right corner of the second page is folded inward.

div.p: I was very glad to get your letter this morning and to know that you are mentioning my lectures in your June number. After all, a laborer is worthy of his meed (sic) of recognition, and that is all I desire.

I am sending you the new “Imagist Anthology”. I suppose you will get an official copy from the publishers, but this is a personal copy. Do review it yourself. I would much rather hear what you have to say about it than what anybody else, whom you might ask to do it, would say. You will see that we have given you a handsome little tribute in the <quote type="english”> “Acknowledgements” , which I had printed in large print on purpose, to make it more noticeable. You see, it is tit for tat, my dear. But tutting without tatting is no fun.
Here is the $25.00for Alice Henderson. I did not send it before, and I am most delighted to send it now. I thought her article on “The School of I-am-it”in the last number was excellent.
Benét wrote me that he thought “Pyrotechnics” was the best poem in that number, which is pleasant to hear.

I was awfully sorry not to see your brother and sister when they passed through Boston. Mrs. Monroe did not let me know that they were here until the morning of the day they left, and unfortunately we could not fit our engagements so as to meet. It was a great disappointment to me, as I should have liked to have entertained them. You must tell them in future they must let me know before, so that I can give them a splendid welcome.
